questions.text: Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the normally protective immune system responds abnormally, potentially harming the body. Which of the following is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the immune system overreacts to a foreign stimulus, resulting in tissue damage. All hypersensitivity shares the common motif of pre-sensitization or pre-exposure to an antigen with a prior immune response.  

There are three specific mechanisms by which type II hypersensitivity reactions occur.  

  • Complement-dependent reactions (inflammation): Antibody bound to antigen can fix complement and induce direct lysis of the cell through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC), or the complement can coat cells with C3b (an opsonin) and promote phagocytosis of the antigen. Example: Goodpasture syndrome, Rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection. 
 
  • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction): Cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate the removal of antigen. Examples: Transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. 
 
  • Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction: Antibodies themselves affect the function of the antigen. Examples: Graves disease is due to an antibody that activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor, resulting in hyperthyroidism. Myasthenia gravis is due to antibodies against the acetylcholine (ACh) receptor, impairing neuromuscular depolarization. 

Option Analysis

❌ Allergic asthma:
Incorrect: Allergic asthma is an example of type I hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.  
❌ Contact dermatitis  :
Incorrect: Contact dermatitis is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.  
✅ Hemolytic disease of the newborn:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after developing dyspnea, hives, and audible wheezing. The patient accidentally ingested peanuts an hour ago,  to which she has a known allergy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells
Direct tissue damage by irradiated antibiotic agent

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the immune system responds abnormally to a stimulus, resulting in potential harm to the body. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and can be associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis.  

Pathophysiology of type I hypersensitivity reactions involves binding IgE to the surface of mast cells and basophils via high-affinity receptors. This eventually results in cross-linking of IgE by antigens, leading to cellular activation and release of preformed and newly synthesized mediators, including histamine, tryptase, and leukotrienes. These mediators cause vasodilation, increased vasopermeability, and smooth-muscle contraction. The effects of these molecules are termed “early phase reactions'', as they happen within minutes of the second exposure.  

There are also “late-phase reactions,” which happen 8-12 hours after exposure, where TH2 cells, eosinophils, and basophils are recruited to the site of allergen exposure. These include interleukin-4, interleukin-5, and interleukin-10, and leukotrienes. These mediators perform various cellular activities, including smooth muscle contraction, further release of histamine, and chemotaxis of neutrophils, mast cells, and additional eosinophils.  

Examples of type I hypersensitivity reactions include ingested allergens like foods, dander, bee stings, mold, drugs/medications, and pollen. Common allergens include latex, lotions, soaps, and penicillin. Some allergic diseases include atopic eczema, allergic urticaria, allergic rhinitis (Hay fever), allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis.  

Option Analysis

✅ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Immune complex-mediated complement activation:
Incorrect: Immune complex-mediated complement activation defines the mechanism of a type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by the deposition of IgG-antigen complexes in various tissues. Examples include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis. This patient presents with anaphylaxis, which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells:
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Although drug reactions caused by cephalosporins like ceftriaxone often result in skin lesions, they are typically maculopapular or morbilliform in appearance and manifest 12–48 hours following exposure. Examples include allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.  
❌ Perivascular cutaneous polymorphonuclear infiltration:
Incorrect: Perivascular cutaneous polymorphonuclear infiltration is typical of cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis. Although these conditions can cause urticarial lesions following exposure, they more commonly manifest with painful, palpable purpura, ulceration, and petechiae. Moreover, these symptoms are antibody-mediated and usually occur weeks after exposure.  
❌ Direct tissue damage by irradiated antibiotic agent:
Incorrect: Direct skin tissue damage through irradiation of an antibiotic agent (a drug-induced photosensitivity reaction) causes an intense sunburn of exposed skin within hours of sun exposure. Cephalosporins do not induce photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune condition characterized as a type II hypersensitivity reaction. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this disease?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the immune system overreacts to a foreign stimulus, resulting in tissue damage. All hypersensitivity shares the common motif of pre-sensitization or pre-exposure to an antigen with a prior immune response.    

There are three specific mechanisms by which type II hypersensitivity reactions occur.  
 
  • Complement-dependent reactions (inflammation): Antibody bound to antigen can fix complement and induce direct lysis of the cell through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC), or the complement can coat cells with C3b (an opsonin) and promote phagocytosis of the antigen. Example: Goodpasture syndrome, Rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection. 
 
  • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction): Cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate the removal of antigen. Examples: Transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. 
 
  • Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction: Antibodies themselves affect the function of the antigen. Examples: Graves disease is due to an antibody that activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor, resulting in hyperthyroidism. Myasthenia gravis is due to antibodies against the acetylcholine (ACh) receptor, impairing neuromuscular depolarization. 

Option Analysis

❌ Complement-dependent reaction:
Incorrect: With complement-dependent reaction, antibody bound to antigen can fix complement and induce direct lysis of the cell through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC), or the complement can coat cells with C3b (an opsonin) and promote phagocytosis of the antigen. Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, Rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection.  
❌ Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity:
Incorrect: With antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction), cells that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate removal of antigen. Examples include transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
✅ Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Immune complex-mediated complement activation  :
Incorrect: Immune complex-mediated complement activation defines a type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by tissue deposition of IgG-antigen complexes. Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis.  
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells:
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for routine follow-up in the springtime. The patient reports frequent sneezing, rhinorrhea and watery eyes since she started training for an upcoming marathon. Past medical history is also notable for well-controlled asthma. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler on an as-needed basis. The patient does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F ), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a prominent nasal crease. The nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray. There is a copious thin and watery nasal mucus. The physician starts the patient on oral loratadine. The mechanism of this medication is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sneezing, rhinorrhea and watery eyes consistent with allergic rhinitis.  Allergic rhinitis is an example of a Type I, or IgE mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Histamine is a small molecule stored in mast cells and basophils that mediates allergic, inflammatory and other physiologic processes throughout the body by binding to four different receptors (H1, H2, H3, H4).  Histamine plays an important role in Type I hypersensitivity reactions by binding to H1 receptors, causing local inflammation and vasodilation.

In a Type 1 allergic reaction, an allergen, such as pollen, enters the body and activates B cells. Activated B-cells produce IgE antibodies that get released into the bloodstream and bind to mast cells. The mast cells are now “primed,” meaning that if pollen enters the body again in the future, the mast cells degranulate and release their histamine into the local tissue.

Antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine and loratadine) reduce itching, sneezing, and rhinorrhea by blocking H1 receptors on endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, sensory nerve endings, and in the brain.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Antagonism of H1 receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Antagonism of H2 receptors:
Incorrect: H2 antagonists target the H2 receptors found in gastric parietal cells.  They are effective in the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux and peptic ulcers by blocking gastric acid secretion, but are not useful in the treatment of allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Stimulation of somatostatin receptors:
Incorrect: Somatostatin receptors agonists (e.g. octreotide) inhibit bioactive amine release and are used to treat diarrhea in patients with carcinoid syndrome and VIPoma.  
❌ Antagonism of nicotinic receptors:
Incorrect: Nicotinic receptor antagonists (e.g. rocuronium) are used to induce paralysis in preparation for surgery and endotracheal intubation. They are not effective in allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Antagonism of serotonin 5-HT3 receptors:
Incorrect: Serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonists (e.g. ondansetron) are used primarily to treat nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual comes to the physician due to low-grade fever and skin discoloration. The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy three days ago. The surgery was complicated by an episode of acute hemorrhaging when an artery was inadvertently ligated, and the patient was given two units of blood. The patient’s postoperative period was normal without any complications, and the patient was discharged yesterday. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 120/80, and pulse is 70/minute. On physical examination, the physician notices skin pallor and mild jaundice in the patient’s eyes. The patient’s incisions are healing well without any discharge, bleeding, or erythema. The abdomen is soft with appropriate tenderness in the area of the incision. Both legs are symmetrical in circumference with no signs of swelling, warmth, or tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with mild jaundice and low-grade fever three days after the patient had an operation and was given blood transfusion. One of the important differential diagnoses that should be suspected is a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction. 

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions are a complication of blood transfusions that result from antibodies that form against minor RBC antigens (e.g. Rh) transfused to patients. Before the transfusion, the titers of these antibodies are usually very low. However, after exposure to the antigens on transfused RBCs, more antibodies start forming, and within days, hemolysis occurs. This hemolysis mostly occurs extravascularly and is typically much more mild than acute hemolytic reactions (which are mostly due to ABO incompatibility).  

Patients with delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction typically present between 24 hours and one month of a transfusion with low-grade fevers and jaundice. However, many patients are usually asymptomatic. The serum bilirubin will be mildly elevated, and the patient's hemoglobin might decrease. Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions are rarely serious, and management is usually supportive.  

Option Analysis

✅ Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical site infection :
Incorrect: Although surgical site infections can lead to fever post-operatively, this complication is unlikely to be the cause in this patient as their incisions are without any pain, discharge, or erythema. 
❌ Postcholecystectomy syndrome:
Incorrect: Postcholecystectomy syndrome (PCS) is defined as the persistence of biliary colic (right upper quadrant pain) along with other gastrointestinal symptoms after cholecystectomy. The condition can occur early after the operation or years later. However, this patient is experiencing mild fever and jaundice without biliary colic, making PCS an unlikely diagnosis.
❌ Deep venous thrombosis:
Incorrect: Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is one of the causes of postoperative fever. However, this patient does not show signs of deep venous thrombosis (e.g., leg pain, unilateral leg swelling). Additionally, DVT does not usually cause jaundice. 
❌ Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction :
Incorrect: Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions can cause fever within 1-6 hours after transfusion; however, the condition does not typically occur after more than 24 hours.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old individual comes to the physician due to fever for the last three days. The patient has a history of diabetic nephropathy and chronic kidney failure and underwent successful kidney transplantation one month ago. The patient is currently taking tacrolimus. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 88/minute, and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. On physical examination, tenderness is noted in the graft site. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Chart review from the previous visit two weeks ago shows a serum creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL. BK virus DNA PCR test is negative. The patient is referred for a biopsy from the transplanted kidney. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histological examination of the biopsy?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  147 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.5 mEq/L 
 Blood urea nitrogen  30 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  2.3 mg/dL

choices.text: Dense mononuclear infiltration of the interstitium and necrosis of the arterial wall
Widespread thrombosis of the graft vessels
Interstitial inflammation, tubular fibrosis with basophilic intranuclear inclusions
Interstitial fibrosis with arteriolar hyalinosis and tubular vacuolization

questions.solution:
This patient has fever, graft site tenderness, and abnormal kidney function test one month after kidney transplantation. This presentation is concerning for acute graft rejection. Although the incidence of acute renal graft rejection has decreased immensely after the introduction of immunosuppressant drugs, it is still one of the leading causes of rejection.  
Acute rejection develops due to recognition of the graft antigens by the immune system, and it results from two immunological immune responses that act in combination or alone: the cellular and the humoral immune responses. The cellular response is mediated by T-cells, which directly recognize MHC antigens on the graft and cause damage to the graft (T-cell dependent process), while the humoral response develops when B cells are recruited (by T-helper cells) and generate antibodies that cause acute humoral rejection (B-cell dependent process). Therefore, acute rejection is considered a type II (antibody-mediated) and type IV (cellular-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction.  

Acute rejection develops from one week to three months after transplantation, and patients usually complain of fever and graft site tenderness. Additionally, there is typically decreased function of the transplanted organ; for example, patients with acute renal graft rejection develop anuria, metabolic abnormalities (e.g. hyperkalemia), and elevated serum creatinine, as seen in this patient.  

A biopsy is needed to diagnose acute graft rejection and differentiate it from other diagnoses (e.g. tacrolimus toxicity). Histologically, acute graft rejection is characterized by mononuclear lymphocytic infiltrate in the interstitium of the graft tissue along with necrosis of the arterial walls (vasculitis).  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Option Analysis

✅ Dense mononuclear infiltration of the interstitium and necrosis of the arterial wall:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interstitial fibrosis with tubular atrophy :
Incorrect: Interstitial fibrosis with tubular atrophy is seen in chronic transplant rejection, not acute transplant rejection. 
❌ Widespread thrombosis of the graft vessels:
Incorrect: Widespread thrombosis of the graft vessels is seen in patients with hyperacute transplant rejection, not acute transplant rejection.
❌ Interstitial inflammation, tubular fibrosis with basophilic intranuclear inclusions :
Incorrect: BK virus is an opportunistic infection of transplanted kidneys that can lead to nephritis and graft failure. On histology, viral basophilic intranuclear inclusions can be seen in addition to interstitial inflammation and varying degrees of tubular atrophy and fibrosis. However, this patient has a negative BK DNA PCR test, making BK virus infection less likely the cause.  
❌ Interstitial fibrosis with arteriolar hyalinosis and tubular vacuolization:
Incorrect: Tacrolimus toxicity on histology is characterized by interstitial fibrosis, arteriolar hyalinosis, and tubular vacuolization. In addition, patients may show acute tubular necrosis. However, tacrolimus nephrotoxicity occurs due to vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles of the kidney, causing prerenal kidney injury where the BUN:Cr ratio is >20 (unlike this patient).

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual develops severe shortness of breath four hours after a blood transfusion was started in the emergency department. The patient was involved in a road traffic accident and was given 3 units of blood in the emergency department. Past medical history is noncontributory. They have no history of prior blood transfusions. On admission, vital signs showed temperature 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse 100/minute, respiratory rate 13/minute, and blood pressure 100/70. Reevaluation of vital signs now show temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 120/minute, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 22/minute. Oxygen saturation has dropped from 97% to 88% on room air. Complete blood count shows leukopenia. The transfusion is stopped immediately, and subsequent chest radiography shows bilateral lung infiltrate. Pulmonary arterial wedge pressure is 10 mmHg (normal = 6-12 mmHg). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), one of the deadliest complications of blood transfusions.  

TRALI is a rare but life-threatening complication of blood transfusion; it is defined as an acute lung injury that develops within six hours of blood transfusion. TRALI is one of the causes of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, in which left ventricular function is normal. Although the pathophysiology of TRALI is not yet completely understood, it is believed that the condition develops secondary to the presence of anti-leukocyte antibodies (e.g. anti-HLA antibodies) in the donor’s plasma. These antibodies bind to recipient neutrophils and lead to their activation in the pulmonary capillaries. This activation then initiates an inflammatory response in the pulmonary capillaries, causing endothelial cell damage, massive cytokine release, and pulmonary edema.    

Patients with TRALI develop severe shortness of breath within six hours of transfusion, commonly along with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension or hypertension. Hypoxemia develops and is characterized by oxygen saturation <90% and a ratio of PaO2/FiO2 <300. Chest radiography shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and pulmonary edema. Because left ventricular function is normal, pulmonary artery wedge pressure is normal at ≤18 mm Hg. Finally, leukopenia and neutropenia are commonly seen in patients with TRALI.  



It is important to differentiate TRALI from transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). TACO is also an acute transfusion complication that develops after transfusion of massive amounts of blood. It is characterized by hypervolemia. Like TRALI, TACO usually presents with acute dyspnea associated with bilateral pulmonary edema. However, TACO is associated with decreased left ventricular ejection fraction, which is normal in TRALI. In addition, because TACO is a volume overload state, it is associated with jugular venous distension, elevation of beta natriuretic peptide (BNP), and sometimes an S3 can be heard. All of these are not seen in patients with TRALI.  



Option Analysis

✅ Transfusion-related acute lung injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anaphylactic transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: Anaphylactic transfusion reactions develop within minutes of transfusion; this reaction is characterized by fever, urticaria, pruritus, and wheezes. Pulmonary edema, hypoxemia, and leukopenia are not usually seen. 
❌ Sepsis:
Incorrect: Sepsis is a rare complication of blood transfusion and is characterized by fever, hypotension, and shock. However, pulmonary edema is not usually seen. 
❌ Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is characterized by a triad of fever, back pain, and red urine. Pulmonary edema and hypoxemia are not seen. 
❌ Transfusion-associated circulatory overload:
Incorrect: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) is one of the differential diagnoses of acute shortness of breath after blood transfusion, along with transfusion-associated acute lung injury (TRALI). However, TACO is also associated with jugular venous distention and sometimes S3 heart sounds (suggestive of cardiac overload)—none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, unlike TRALI, TACO is associated with elevated pulmonary arterial wedge pressure.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old individual is brought to the emergency department by an ambulance after they were involved in a road traffic accident. The patient is unconscious and suffered from multiple lacerations affecting the face, arms, and legs. During the transfer of the patient, the paramedics performed endotracheal intubation to secure the airway. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals an unconscious adult with several lacerations. A complete blood count is ordered, and the patient is given 2 units of blood. Several minutes after the transfusion started, the patient’s blood pressure drops to 60/40 mmHg. Auscultation of the lungs reveals diffuse wheezing. Skin examination also reveals the findings shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Recipient’s antibodies against transfused plasma proteins
Recipient’s antibodies against transfused red blood cells
Donor’s plasma antibodies against recipient’s white blood cells
Cytokines produced by donor’s white blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient developed hypotension and urticaria minutes after a blood transfusion was started, indicating a transfusion reaction – specifically an anaphylactic/allergic blood transfusion reaction.  

An anaphylactic transfusion reaction is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that usually develops within minutes after the onset of transfusion. It occurs due to the recipient's pre-formed antibodies reacting against plasma proteins found in the transfused blood. These antibodies are mostly IgG and IgE antibodies. Once these antibodies bind to the antigen, they cause a systemic anaphylaxis by inducing degranulation of mast cells and basophils. Although anaphylactic transfusion reactions are rare, they can be fatal and must be identified immediately.  

Anaphylactic transfusion reactions are characterized by urticaria, pruritus, and wheezing, in addition to chills and rigors, that develop within minutes of the transfusion. Hypotension can sometimes develop (such as in this patient), and in severe cases, the patient may progress to anaphylactic shock.  



Option Analysis

✅ Recipient’s antibodies against transfused plasma proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recipient’s antibodies against transfused red blood cells :
Incorrect: An acute hemolytic reaction occurs when an incorrect blood group is given to a patient, leading to hemolysis of RBCs. It is characterized by fever, hypotension, and hemoglobinuria. However, urticaria is not seen.
❌ Donor’s plasma antibodies against recipient’s white blood cells:
Incorrect: Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) occurs when donor antibodies against the recipient's leukocytes lead to neutrophil activation in the pulmonary circulation and subsequent pulmonary injury. The condition is characterized by acute shortness of breath, pulmonary edema, and hypotension. TRALI develops in hours, not minutes as seen in this patient, and is not associated with urticaria. 
❌ Bacteria-contaminated transfused blood:
Incorrect: Rarely, units of blood may be contaminated with bacteria or bacterial products (e.g. endotoxins), which may cause septic shock in the recipient. However, urticaria is not typically seen.
❌ Cytokines produced by donor’s white blood cells:
Incorrect: A febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction is the most common transfusion reaction; it is due to cytokines produced by the leukocytes in the donor’s blood. However, urticaria and hypotension are not seen.

questions.text: A 58-year-old individual with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the physician to discuss the option of kidney transplantation. The patient developed renal failure secondary to glomerulosclerosis 15 years ago. The patient underwent a successful kidney transplantation 10 years ago from a related donor, but the transplant failed and was removed three years ago. The patient is currently on hemodialysis. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a deep venous thrombosis in the left lower extremity, now resolved. After significant deliberation, the patient undergoes a kidney transplantation from a non-related donor. Eight hours after the surgery,  the patient develops chills, malaise, and fever. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 104/70, and pulse is 102/minute. The patient has not made urine in the past five hours. The surgeon suspects complications with the transplanted organ, and the patient is brought back to the operating room. On open laparotomy, the transplanted kidney appears mottled and cyanotic. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Mixed type II and IV hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
This patient most likely developed hyperacute transplant rejection of the transplant kidney. Hyperacute transplant rejection is a type II (antibody-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction and is a rare form of transplant rejection.  

Hyperacute transplant rejection occurs due to preformed anti-donor antibodies (e.g. anti-donor HLA antibodies) that are present before transplantation, which most commonly formed from previous failed grafts (such as in this patient), previous transfusions, or previous pregnancies. Once the transplanted organ is perfused, these antibodies attack it, leading to activation of the complement system and coagulation system. This activation ultimately results in vessel thrombosis, organ ischemia and necrosis, and graft loss. The difference between hyperacute and acute rejection is the presence of preformed antibodies that cause rejection immediately in hyperacute rejections, while in acute rejection, antibodies are formed after transplantation and, therefore, the reaction takes more time (i.e. several months).  

Hyperacute transplant rejection starts within minutes after transplantation and continues for up to 48 hours. Patients usually have fever, malaise, and chills, in addition to decreased function of the transplanted organ (e.g. decreased urine output in kidney transplantation). Unfortunately, hyperacute transplant rejection is an irreversible form of rejection, and thus the only treatment is removal of the transplanted organ.  

The transplanted organ usually appears mottled and cyanosed after hyperacute transplant rejection. Under histopathological examination, there is widespread thrombosis seen in the graft, in addition to signs of cellular necrosis.    

Option Analysis

❌ Type I hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions develop due to activation and cross-linking of IgE receptors on presensitized mast cells. Examples of type I hypersensitivity reactions include anaphylaxis and allergic asthma. However, hyperacute transplant rejection is a type II, not type I, hypersensitivity reaction.
✅ Type II hypersensitivity reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Type III hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type III hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibody-antigen complexes that deposit in various tissues (e.g., joints, skin) and induce an inflammatory response. Serum sickness is one common example of type III hypersensitivity reactions. However, hyperacute transplant rejection is a type II, not type III, hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by T-cells (both CD4+ and CD8+). Acute rejection, chronic rejection, and graft-versus-host reactions all involve type IV hypersensitivity reactions. However, hyperacute transplant rejection is a type II, not type IV, hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Mixed type II and IV hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Acute and chronic transplant rejections have both type II (antibody-mediated) and type IV (cytotoxic-mediated) hypersensitivity reactions. However, hyperacute transplant rejection is purely a type II, not type IV, hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, undergoes a cesarean section for the delivery of her baby. The operation is complicated by excessive bleeding, and the patient is given 3 units of blood. Two hours later, the patient’s temperature rises from 37°C (98.6°F) to 38.1°C (100.6°F). In addition, she begins experiencing chills. The blood transfusion is immediately stopped, and the patient is given intravenous normal saline. Thirty minutes later, the patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 100/80, and pulse is 95/minute. The patient has no known history of illnesses and has never received blood products in the past. Which of the following best explains the fever that the patient developed?

choices.text: Bacterial contamination of the transfused blood
Recipient’s antibodies against donor plasma proteins

questions.solution:
This patient developed fever and chills two hours after a blood transfusion, which resolved spontaneously. This presentation is consistent with a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction, which is the most common transfusion reaction.   

A febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction is a common, mild condition. It develops due to two events:  

1. The most common mechanism is that leukocytes in the donor’s blood produce cytokines when stored, and once transfused, these cytokines stimulate the hypothalamus, causing elevation of body temperature.
2. Another mechanism is that the recipient produces antibodies against the HLA antigen on the donor’s leukocytes, and these antibodies attack the donor’s leukocytes and lyse them, causing fevers.

Although these patients usually have isolated fevers, some patients may develop anxiety, chills, and headaches. The fever usually resolves shortly after the blood transfusion is stopped. Aside from the fever, the patient’s vitals are usually stable.  

Although febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions are not life-threatening, if a patient develops this reaction, the patient should be given leukoreduced transfusions in the future. Leukoreduction is a process in which the leukocytes are removed from the donor’s blood. This measure will prevent future febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions from developing since the transfused leukocytes will not produce cytokines, and the recipient’s antibodies will not attack them.  



Option Analysis

✅ Cytokines produced by donor’s leukocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial contamination of the transfused blood:
Incorrect: Sepsis due to bacterial contamination of blood products can be life-threatening and is characterized by fever, hypotension, and shock. This patient’s fever resolved without antipyretic or antibiotic intervention, and her vitals are stable, making sepsis an unlikely cause.
❌ ABO incompatibility:
Incorrect: Acute hemolytic reactions result from ABO incompatibility, where a different blood group is given to the patient, resulting in hemolysis. Patients usually have fever, flank pain, and red urine; moreover, the condition is unlikely to rapidly resolve on its own as seen in this patient. 
❌ Recipient’s antibodies against donor plasma proteins:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis can develop as a complication of transfusion due to a reaction from the recipient’s antibodies against plasma proteins of the donor blood. However, it is usually characterized by hives, wheezes, pruritus, and, in severe cases, hypotension. These symptoms are not seen in this patient, making anaphylaxis an unlikely cause. 
❌ Bradykinin in blood products :
Incorrect: Bradykinin is found in blood products and is normally degraded by angiotensin-converting enzyme. Patients taking angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) are unable to degrade the bradykinin and may develop hypotension within minutes of blood transfusion. However, this patient does not have hypotension and has developed mild fever and chills within hours of transfusion, making a febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction the most likely cause.

questions.text: A 64-year-old individual undergoes further evaluation by a nephrologist after being found to have elevated blood pressure and proteinuria. The patient underwent successful kidney transplantation two years ago and has been taking tacrolimus daily. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus complicated with diabetic nephropathy and end-stage renal disease. The patient tells the physician that they are not completely adherent to their medication as they sometimes forget to take it. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/minute, and blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. The patient has not had hypertension in the past. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated serum creatinine in addition to proteinuria. A biopsy is taken from the transplanted kidney and shows arteriosclerosis of the transplanted organ vessels in addition to parenchymal fibrosis and tubular atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely having chronic renal transplant rejection. Chronic transplant rejection is one of the most common causes of graft rejection, and it typically develops one year after transplantation. The pathophysiology of chronic graft rejection involves both the cellular and humoral immune responses:  

  •  Antibody-mediated injury (type II hypersensitivity reaction) occurs due to development of donor specific antibodies against HLA and non-HLA antigens. These antibodies induce graft endothelial damage both directly and indirectly via complement activation and recruitment of other immune inflammatory cells.  
  • Cell-mediated injury (type IV hypersensitivity reaction) occurs when antigen-presenting cells (APC) present the graft antigens to the T-cells, leading to T-cell activation. After T-cells are activated, they begin secreting several cytokines, including interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) and transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta). This cytokine release eventually induces an immune response, leading to graft rejection.
Histologically, chronic transplant rejection is characterized by interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, arteriolar hyalinosis, and hyaline arteriolar thickening (arteriosclerosis). However, chronic transplant rejection is organ-specific depending on the transplanted organ. Some organ-specific examples of chronic transplant rejection include:

  1.  Bronchiolitis obliterans is a form of chronic lung transplant rejection.
  2.  Vanishing bile duct syndrome is a form of chronic liver transplant rejection and is characterized by a decreased number of bile ducts and obliteration of small arteries.  
  3. Chronic allograft nephropathy is a form of chronic kidney transplant rejection.

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic transplant rejection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute transplant rejection :
Incorrect: Acute transplant rejection usually occurs between three months to one year following transplant. Histologically, it is characterized by vasculitis and dense lymphocytic interstitial infiltration. This patient most likely has chronic, not acute, rejection.
❌ Hyperacute transplant rejection:
Incorrect: Hyperacute transplant rejection happens minutes to hours after transplant due to preformed antibodies against the graft antigens. It does not occur two years after transplant. 
❌ BK virus nephropathy:
Incorrect: Although BK virus nephropathy can lead to kidney transplant failure, histology typically reveals viral inclusions (i.e. intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions) within kidney cells. 
❌ Calcineurin inhibitor toxicity:
Incorrect: Calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus, cyclosporine) are highly nephrotoxic immunosuppressants. However, the histological findings in this patient instead suggest chronic renal transplant rejection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old individual is brought to the emergency department by a friend after the patient was stabbed in the abdomen in a bar fight. Upon arrival, the patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 116/min and blood pressure is 108/80 mmHg.  The patient has facial pallor with a visible stab wound in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. The patient is immediately resuscitated in the emergency department and is given 2 units of blood. Several minutes after the transfusion, the patient begins having severe itching and scattered hives all over their body. The patient’s blood pressure drops to 60/40. The transfusion is immediately stopped; the patient is given fluids, antihistamines, and intramuscular epinephrine, and the patient’s blood pressure begins to normalize. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient’s blood serum?

choices.text: Bacterial contamination of the transfused blood

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely having anaphylactic transfusion reaction, which develops due to preformed antibodies in the recipient against the donor's plasma proteins, causing mast cell and basophil activation and systemic anaphylaxis.  

Anaphylactic transfusion reactions are rare but potentially fatal and develop more commonly in patients with IgA deficiency. These patients have no IgA and thus form anti-IgA IgG and IgE antibodies that bind to the IgA in the donor's plasma and induce an anaphylaxis reaction. To avoid such life threatening reactions, patients with known IgA deficiency usually wear a medical alert bracelet/necklace indicating their status.  

Patients with IgA deficiency should be given plasma-reduced or washed blood. In washed blood, the plasma is removed and, since the IgA antigens are found in the plasma, removing those antigens will prevent the risk of anaphylactic reactions.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of Anti-IgA antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial contamination of the transfused blood:
Incorrect: Sepsis due to bacterial contamination of blood products can be life-threatening and is characterized by fever, hypotension, and shock. This patient’s fever resolved without antipyretic or antibiotic intervention, and vitals are stable, making sepsis unlikely as the cause.
❌ Circulating antibody-antigen complexes:
Incorrect: Type III hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibody-antigen complexes that deposit in various tissues (e.g., joints, skin) and induce an inflammatory response. Serum sickness is one common example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction. However, this patient’s anaphylaxis is a type I, not type III, hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Presence of Anti-IgE antibodies:
Incorrect: Anaphylactic reactions to blood products are more commonly characterized by the presence of anti-IgA, not anti-IgE antibodies. 
❌ Hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Calcium gluconate infusion is done to prevent hypocalcemia in patients receiving massive amounts of blood. However, hypocalcemia does not manifest as an anaphylactic reaction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old individual presents to the physician for evaluation of persistent diarrhea and a skin rash for the past week. The patient’s diarrhea began one week ago, is watery, and persists even during fasting. Yesterday, the patient noticed blood in the stool as well. In addition, the patient started experiencing a painful rash on their neck, shoulders, and the palms of their hands. The patient was diagnosed with acute leukemia six months ago and received a bone marrow transplantation two months ago after chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a maculopapular rash is noted on the shoulders, arms, palms, and soles. Oral examination reveals the presence of mouth ulcers. On laboratory tests, serum alkaline phosphatase and serum bilirubin are elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Immune response of graft T-cells against recipient’s cells
Immune response of graft B-cells against recipient’s antigens
Immune response of recipient’s T-cells against graft antigens

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), which is a common complication of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Although GVHD is mostly seen in bone marrow transplantation, it can also occur in solid organ transplantation with rich lymphocytes (e.g., liver) or even when giving un-irradiated blood.  

Graft-versus-host disease is a systemic disorder that occurs after the graft’s immune cells recognize the antigens of the host cells and induce damage to the recipient’s tissues. For GVHD to occur, three components must be met:  

 1.      The graft (transplanted organ) must contain immunocompetent cells (e.g. bone marrow transplant).  
 2.      The recipient must be immunocompromised and thus incapable of mounting an immune response to eliminate the transplanted immunocompetent cells.
 3.      The transplanted immune cells must recognize the alloantigens of the host cells as foreign or non-self.

GVHD is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that is mediated by T-cells – specifically, both T-helper cells (CD4+) and cytotoxic T-cells (CD8+) cells. It develops when these donor T-cells recognize antigens on the recipient’s cells due to a mismatch between the major and/or minor histocompatibility antigens between the host and recipient. GVHD develops when the donor T-cells recognize the recipient’s MHC proteins as foreign and induce an inflammatory response damaging the host cells.  



Patients with acute GVHD usually present with a pruritic or painful erythematous maculopapular rash. The rash typically involves the shoulders, nape of the neck, palms, and soles. However, in severe cases, the rash may be generalized, and patients may have blisters and ulcers. In addition, patients usually have gastrointestinal manifestations, including secretory watery diarrhea that persists during fasting and may progress to bloody diarrhea if ulcers in the gastrointestinal tract develop. Some patients may also have vomiting and nausea. Finally, the liver is usually involved (unless the transplanted organ is the liver), which manifests as elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin.  

Finally, despite the harmful consequences of GVHD, it can sometimes be used for beneficial effects in leukemia patients, wherein the donor lymphocytes attack the recipient's malignant cells, a process known as graft versus leukemia effect.   



Option Analysis

✅ Immune response of graft T-cells against recipient’s cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Immune response of graft B-cells against recipient’s antigens :
Incorrect: Graft-versus-host disease is due to host T-cells attacking the recipient’s antigens; B cells are not involved in GVHD. 
❌ Immune response of recipient’s T-cells against graft antigens :
Incorrect: In graft-versus-host disease, the graft T-cells attack and damage the antigens in the recipient. 
❌ Infection with cytomegalovirus :
Incorrect: Patients with immunodeficiency (like this patient) are susceptible to CMV infection, which can lead to colitis. However, the constellation of symptoms (elevated liver enzymes, skin rash, and gastrointestinal symptoms) strongly suggest GVHD as the most likely diagnosis in this case. 
❌ Infection with Mycobacterium avium complex :
Incorrect: MAC can lead to colitis in patients with immunodeficiency. However, skin rashes and elevation of liver enzymes are not seen.

questions.text: A 57-year-old individual is brought to the emergency department by their spouse due to an episode of vomiting blood several hours ago. The patient has a history of chronic alcohol use and was diagnosed with liver cirrhosis two years ago. The patient vomits blood twice in the emergency department. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 108/minute, and blood pressure is 92/62 mmHg. The patient appears to be disoriented. Two intravenous lines are secured, and the patient is started on a blood transfusion. Thirty minutes later, the patient begins experiencing chills and flank pain. In addition, the patient’s urine appears red. The patient’s temperature is now 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 130/minute, and blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Transfusion is immediately stopped, and aggressive hydration is started. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with hematemesis, and given the patient’s history of liver cirrhosis, the most likely cause of the hematemesis is ruptured esophageal varices: a life-threatening complication of liver failure and the most common cause of death in patients with liver cirrhosis. Patients with ruptured varices lose a significant amount of blood and must therefore be stabilized; blood units are given as needed. Upon receipt of this necessary transfusion, this patient developed chills, flank pain, red urine, fever, and hypotension within 30 minutes. This presentation is concerning for an acute hemolytic reaction.   

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is a life-threatening reaction that results most commonly due to ABO incompatibility, in which a different blood group is given to a patient (e.g., patients with blood group type A are given blood type B). These patients have antibodies against different blood types, and upon receipt of a different type of blood, these antibodies directly attack the foreign RBCs, causing both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.  

Patients with acute hemolytic reactions usually manifest with a triad of fever, flank pain, and red urine. Hypotension can develop in severe cases. Because of the toxic effects of hemoglobin on the kidneys, some patients may develop acute kidney injury. Rarely, the reaction may progress to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and death.    

Once an acute transfusion reaction is suspected, the transfusion must be stopped immediately, and vigorous hydration with normal saline should be started immediately. If laboratory values are ordered during an acute episode, patients will have increased serum bilirubin and LDH and decreased serum haptoglobin. On peripheral smear, signs of hemolysis (e.g. spherocytes) can be seen.    



Option Analysis

✅ Acute hemolytic reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Septic shock :
Incorrect: Septic shock is a rare complication of transfusions and is characterized by hypotension, fever, and chills similar to this patient. However, flank pain and red urine suggest an acute hemolytic reaction, not septic shock.
❌ Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: A febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction is a common complication of transfusions and is characterized by fever, chills, and anxiety a few hours after transfusion. However, hypotension, red urine, and flank pain are not seen in febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions.
❌ Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: A delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction is a milder form of hemolytic transfusion reactions that develops a few days after transfusion and is characterized by jaundice. However, this patient is having a reaction within hours of transfusion, indicating an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction.
❌ Anaphylaxis:
Incorrect: Anaphylaxis is characterized by pruritus, wheezing, urticaria, and hypotension minutes after transfusion. Flank pain and red urine are not seen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with end-stage liver disease secondary to chronic hepatitis C infection undergoes liver transplantation. The liver was received from the patient’s daughter. The patient had no complications in the perioperative period and is subsequently started on tacrolimus to decrease the likelihood of transplant rejection.  Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which tacrolimus reduces transplant rejection?
questions.solution:
This patient underwent hepatic transplantation and was given tacrolimus to prevent organ rejection. Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor that is used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients. It can also be used in some autoimmune disorders.  

Tacrolimus exerts its immunosuppressive properties by binding to a protein called FK-binding protein and then inhibiting calcineurin. This suppresses the activation of the Nuclear Factor of Activated T cells (NFAT), which in turn leads to decreased IL-2 production. The lack of IL-2 impairs the proliferation and differentiation of T lymphocytes, which are the main cells responsible for transplant rejection.  

As with cyclosporine, tacrolimus also has vasoconstrictive properties that can lead to nephrotoxicity and hypertension. Neurotoxicity (e.g. convulsions) is more commonly associated with tacrolimus than cyclosporine. On the other hand, tacrolimus is not associated with gingival hyperplasia or hirsutism. Other side effects of tacrolimus include hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia,  and hyperglycemia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Decreases intracellular response to interleukin-2 (IL-2):
Incorrect: Sirolimus decreases the intracellular response to IL-2 by binding to and inhibiting mTOR, inhibiting T cell growth and proliferation in response to IL-2 receptor activation. This patient is receiving tacrolimus.
✅ Inhibits Interleukin-2 (IL-2) production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blocks interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor:
Incorrect: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-2 receptors. It binds to and blocks IL-2 receptors, thereby preventing the action of IL-2 in promoting T cell immune response.
❌ Inhibits purine synthesis:
Incorrect: Azathioprine is an antimetabolite that gets converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits the synthesis of purine bases. This impairs nucleotide synthesis and immune cell proliferation.
❌ Inhibits pyrimidine synthesis:
Incorrect: Methotrexate exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting the synthesis of pyrimidine bases. This impairs immune cell division and proliferation.
